courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Wireless Communication
courses.description: Physical characteristics of radio channels, cellular coverage, noise and interferences; radio modem technologies; channel assignment by frequency, time, or code division; handoffs and mobility management; wide area wireless network case studies: GSM and 3G; local area wireless network case studies: IEEE 802.11 and IEEE 802.15; principles of satellite communications, introduction to GPS system.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty; Exclusion: ESTR4304 or IERG4100
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student should be able to:   
   
Gain the conceptual knowledge in wireless communication, including those specified in the course contents (physical characteristics of radio channels, cellular coverage, noise and interferences; radio modem technologies; channel assignment by frequency, time, or code division; handoffs and mobility management; wide area wireless network)   
Students would also have gone through case studies in contemporary topics in wireless communication.
courses.course_syllabus: Physical characteristics of radio channels, cellular coverage, noise and interferences; radio modem technologies; channel assignment by frequency, time, or code division; handoffs and mobility management; wide area wireless network case studies: GSM and 3G; local area wireless network case studies: IEEE 802.11 and IEEE 802.15; principles of satellite communications, introduction to GPS system.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and informal feedback channels:   
- Two course evaluations. First one to be conducted in the middle of the term and the second one at the end of the term. Students are encouraged to provide specific comments and/or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.    
- Students are also encouraged to provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, course newsgroup, or simply discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: Wireless Communications" by Andrea Goldsmith, Cambridge University Press, 2005. ISBN: 0-521-83716-2

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Optical Communication and Lightwave Networks
courses.description: Optical fiber and transmission characteristics, optical sources (lasers and light-emitting diodes) and transmitters, photodetectors and optical receivers, optical passive and active components: couplers, filters, switches, modulators, EDFA and Raman amplifiers, etc., optical system design, lightwave systems and networks: undersea systems, optical multia-access network design, SONET/SDH, fiber-in-the-loop, passive optical networks, optical network management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty;Exclusion: ELEG3303 or ESTR3206 or IERG4030
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student should be able to:   
   
Gain conceptual knowledge in optical communication and lightwave networks. Including those specified in the course content (Optical fiber and transmission characteristics, optical sources (lasers and light-emitting diodes) and transmitters, photodetectors and optical receivers, optical passive and active components: couplers, filters, switches, modulators, EDFA and Raman amplifiers, etc., optical system design, lightwave systems and networks: undersea systems, optical multi-access network design, SONET/SDH, fiber-in-the-loop, passive optical networks, optical network management).
courses.course_syllabus: Optical fiber and transmission characteristics, optical sources (lasers and light-emitting diodes) and transmitters, photodetectors and optical receivers, optical passive and active components: couplers, filters, switches, modulators, EDFA and Raman amplifiers, etc., optical system design, lightwave systems and networks: undersea systems, optical multia-access network design, SONET/SDH, fiber-in-the-loop, passive optical networks, optical network management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and informal feedback channels:   
   
- Two course evaluations. First one to be conducted in the middle of the term and the second one at the end of the term. Students are encouraged to provide specific comments and/or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.    
   
- Students are also encouraged to provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, course newsgroup, or simply discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
1) Optical Fiber Communications, 3rd Ed. by G. Keiser, McGraw-Hill, 2000   
2) Fiber-Optic Communications Systems, 3rd Ed. by G.P. Agrawal, Wiley-Interscience, 2002   
3) Lightwave Technology: Components and Devices by G.P. Agrawal, Wiley-Interscience, 2004

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Multimedia Coding and Applications
courses.description: Digital text, image, audio and video coding techniques; digital image and video processing; standard of video compression: MPEG and H.261; advanced topics in multimedia systems and applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty;Exclusion: IERG4190
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student should be able to:   

At the completion of this course, the student should be able to:

 

Gain conceptual knowledge in multimedia coding and processing. Including those as specified in the course content (Digital text, image, audio and video coding techniques; digital image and video processing; standard of video compression: MPEG and H.261; advanced topics in multimedia systems and applications.)

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Emerging Topics in Information Engineering

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 1004
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 1004
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 1004

courses.description: This course will introduce to the students emerging topics in information engineering. The detailed course contents may be changed from year to year depending on the current development and the teacher specialty. Course assessment is at the discretion of course teacher.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:

1. apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering appropriate to the degree discipline.   
   
2. use the computer/IT tools relevant to the discipline along with an understanding of their processes and limitations.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Cryptography, Information Security and Privacy
courses.description: This course aims to enhance students’ knowledge in cryptography as well as information security and privacy, in both theoretical and practical ways. The course introduces cryptography at an elementary level, enabling students to appreciate on its application to information security and privacy. Daily applications of cryptography will be discussed, including digital certificate and Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), Virtual Private Network (VPN), wireless communication security, as well as security and privacy issues in online social networks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:   
1. gain conceptual knowledge in cryptography, security, and privacy; and   
2. completed case studies in contemporary topics in cryptography, security, and privacy, such as security audit, and digital right management.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course aims to enhance students’ knowledge in cryptography as well as information security and privacy, in both theoretical and practical ways. The course introduces cryptography at an elementary level, enabling students to appreciate on its application to information security and privacy. Daily applications of cryptography will be discussed, including digital certificate and Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), Virtual Private Network (VPN), wireless communication security, as well as security and privacy issues in online social networks.   
The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:   
   
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.    
   
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: Textbook: Atul Kahate, Cryptography and Network Security. (2003)

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Innovation and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Entrepreneur characteristics; product innovation: factors driving innovation, creation and evaluation of new product ideas, risk assessment of commercialization, critical factors for success; business planning: market assessment and strategy, business model, product planning, financial planning, cash flow; financing options, negotiation and deals; formation of a new venture: team, company and product building; execution and dealing with reality; exit strategies; case studies related to innovation and entrepreneurship in information engineering.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students
Exclusion: CMSC5730 or ENGG3802 or ENGG3803 or ENGG5700 or ESTR3502 or FTEC5570 or IERG5340 or SEEM3450
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) The students will learn the 4 aspects of a framework of Entrepreneurship, namely

•Identification of Opportunity  
•Venture Design (includes Business Model Design and Organization Design)  
•Resource Mobilization  
•Venture Execution

b) The students will learn the typical stages from idea creation to the formation of a startup company, with successful venture capital funding and management team in place.

c) They also learn how other entrepreneurs make decisions, do deals, analyze problems, allocate and mobilize scarce resources and succeed in local or even an international context.
courses.course_syllabus: Entrepreneur characteristics; product innovation: factors driving innovation, creation and evaluation of new product ideas, risk assessment of commercialization, critical factors for success; business planning: market assessment and strategy, business model, product planning, financial planning, cash flow; financing options, negotiation and deals; formation of a new venture: team, company and product building; execution and dealing with reality; exit strategies; case studies related to innovation and entrepreneurship in information engineering.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and informal feedback channels:

- Two course evaluations.  First one to be conducted in the middle of the term and the second one at the end of the term. Students are encouraged to provide specific comments and/or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

- Students are also encouraged to provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, course newsgroup, or simply discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings:
None   

None
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Jeff Timmons and Stephen Spinelli           New Venture Creation, Entrepreneurship for the 21st Century McGraw-Hill
2. John Nesheim.                  High Tech Start Up.    Free Press, 2000.
3. Clayton Christensen         Innovator’s Dilemma  Harvard Business School Press
4. Clayton Christensen         Innovators’ Solution   Harvard Business School Press
5. Clayton M. Christensen, Scott D. Anthony, and Erik A. Roth   Seeing What’s Next: Using the Theories of Innovation to Predict Industry Change                      Harvard Business School Press (2004)
6. Hagiu, Evans and Schmalensee    Invisible Engines                     MIT Press
7. Evans and Schmalensee               Catalyst Code                         Harvard Business School Press
8. Henry Chesbrough                       Open Business Models           HBS Press
9. Steve Kemper                               Code Named Ginger               HBS Press
10. Ali Farhoomand   Small Business Management and Entrepreneurship in HK: A Casebook HKU Press
11. John Mullins & Randy Komisar Getting to Plan B: Breaking Through to a Better Business Model Harvard Business Press (2009)
12. Waishun Lo          Cases Study of HK High Tech Startups         Joint Publisher, 1999

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Emerging Communication Technologies
courses.description: The course covers the principles and applications of various emerging communication and networking technologies to support the current high-capacity and flexible telecommunication data networks. The topics include telecommunication network infrastructures, optical fiber transport and access networks, mobile cellular systems and emerging wireless networking technologies, cloud/fog/edge computing, software-defined networking and network virtualization, distributed systems for big data analytics, and network control and management.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
Exclusion: IERG4340
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:   
   
1. Learn the basic principles of the state-of-art communication technologies to support the current telecommunication networks.   
   
2. Learn about the various applications of the emerging communication technologies.
courses.course_syllabus: The course covers the principles and applications of various emerging communication and networking technologies to support the current high-capacity and flexible telecommunication data networks. The topics include telecommunication network infrastructures, optical fiber transport and access networks, mobile cellular systems and emerging wireless networking technologies, cloud/fog/edge computing, software-defined networking and network virtualization, distributed systems for big data analytics, and network control and management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:   
   
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.   
   
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Optical Fiber Telecommunications, volumes III, IV, V, VI, Academic Press.   
   
2. Smart Grid Communications and Networking, Cambridge University Press.   
   
3. An introduction to LTE: LTE, LTE-Advanced, SAW and 4G Mobile Communications, Wiley.   
   
4. Internet of Things (A Hands-on Approach), VPT.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Web Programming and Internet Security

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description: The World-Wide Web increasingly becomes the popular choice for delivering interactive applications, offering advantages such as instantaneous access, automated upgrade, online collaboration. This course introduces web technologies including client-side scripting, server programming, database, and user interface. It also briefly describes other related topics such as free/open hosting platforms and SaaS (Software as a Service), open API, virtualized servers on cloud. RIA (Rich Internet Application) across the online and mobile networks. Students also learn web programming concepts, and learn common web security threats and how to avoid them. Hands-on projects may be used to enhance the experience and the appreciation of the topics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty;Exclusion: IERG4210
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student should be able to  
   
1. Design and implement secure dynamic web applications using core technologies such as Javascript and AJAX.  
   
2. Have sound technical knowledge about latest trends in web applications such as SaaS (Software as a Service), social   
   
networks, and cloud computing
courses.course_syllabus: The World-Wide Web increasingly becomes the popular choice for delivering interactive applications, offering advantages such as instantaneous access, automated upgrade, online collaboration. This course introduces web technologies including client-side scripting, server programming, database, and user interface. It also briefly describes other related topics such as free/open hosting platforms and SaaS (Software as a Service), open API, virtualized servers on cloud. RIA (Rich Internet Application) across the online and mobile networks. Students also learn web programming concepts, and learn common web security threats and how to avoid them. Hands-on projects may be used to enhance the experience and the appreciation of the topics. (Not for students who have taken IERG4210 or CMSC5729)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and informal feedback channels:  
   
- Two course evaluations. First one to be conducted in the middle of the term and the second one at the end of the term.   
   
Students are encouraged to provide specific comments and/or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.  
   
 - Students are also encouraged to provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, course newsgroup, or simply discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings:
This course uses a combination of online materials and optional textbooks. They include:  
   
Textbooks:  
   
1. Google Browseer Security Handbook (free online resources).  
   
2. Javascript: The Definitive Guide. 5th Edition, by David Flanagan, O'Reilly, 2006  
   
3. The Web Application Hacker's Handbook: Discovering and Exploiting Security Flaws, by . Stuttard and M. Pinto, Wiley 2007  
   
Course web page and supplementary download materials shall be maintained by the Teacher and his TA's.
courses.recommended_readings: None

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Technology Strategy

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2
Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2

courses.description: This course introduces technology strategy and management. The challenges of technology companies (such as hardware, software, internet, consumer electronics, communications and networking) regardless they are in startup or mature stage, are very different from other industries. They need to consider five aspects carefully to formulate an effective strategy. A framework of strategy in technology-intensive companies will be introduced. This framework consists of 5 components:1. Network Effects2. Multi-sided Platforms3. Intellectual Property (IP) and Standards4. Technology Commercialization5. Digital Convergence
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to analyze the strategy of technology companies and able to use the framework and Innovation Theory to answer questions such as:    
1. Which technologies should a firm explore and develop?    
2. How likely will the consumer adopt these new technologies and innovations?    
3. What is Disruptive Innovation as defined by Clayton Christensen?    
4. How can Open Innovation help companies?    
5. How can technology be leveraged to build standards and multi-sided platforms?    
6. Should firms partner with other companies which could become their competitors (recent example is Nokia/Microsoft partnership)?   
7. How can firms capture value from their R&D and innovations and sustain value despite wide-spread imitation and new technologies emerging?
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces technology strategy and management. The challenges of technology companies (such as hardware, software, internet, consumer electronics, communications and networking) regardless they are in startup or mature stage, are very different from other industries. They need to consider five aspects carefully to formulate an effective strategy. A framework of strategy in technology-intensive companies will be introduced. This framework consists of 5 components:    
1. Network Effects   
2. Multi-sided Platforms   
3. Intellectual Property (IP) and Standards   
4. Technology Commercialization   
5. Digital Convergence   
The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructors directly.

This course uses a combination of online materials and optional textbooks. They include:    
Textbooks:    
1. Clayton Christensen Innovator' s Dilemma Harvard Business School Press.    
2. Clayton Christensen Innovator's Solution Harvard Business School Press.    
3. Hagiu, Evans and Schmalensee Invisible Engines MIT Press.    
4. Evans and Schmalensee Catalyst Code Harvard Business School Press.    
5. Henry Chesbrough Open Business Models HBS Press.

8. Steve Kemper Code Named Ginger HBS Press.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Social Networking
courses.description: Social networking concerned with the conduction of various social behaviors over the internet, as well as the underlying technologies. It is an interdisciplinary subject involving multiple fields including computer networks and applications, psychology, as well as sociology. This course provides a holistic overview on both technology and humanity aspects of social networks, with emphases on the social sciences aspects and perspectives. It covers topics such as social network analysis (e.g. discourse analysis, semantics, social network pattern), network-mediated knowledge building and collaboration, epistemology in social networks, and applications of social networks in business and education.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student should   

At the completion of this course, the student should

1. gain knowledge and understanding in both technical and humanity aspects of social networks
2. be able to perform basic social network analysis
3. be familiar with and experienced in advanced usage of social networks; and
4. be able to propose applications of social networks in areas such as business and education.
courses.course_syllabus: Social networking concerned with the conduction of various social behaviors over the internet, as well as the underlying technologies. It is an interdisciplinary subject involving multiple fields including computer networks and applications, psychology, as well as sociology. This course provides a holistic overview on both technology and humanity aspects of social networks, with emphases on the social sciences aspects and perspectives. It covers topics such as social network analysis (e.g. discourse analysis, semantics, social network pattern), network-mediated knowledge building and collaboration, epistemology in social networks, and applications of social networks in business and education.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Broadband Access Technologies
courses.description: The course aims to introduce various advanced wireline (copper wire and optical fiber) and wireless communication technologies to realize first-mile broadband access for video and data services. The wireline technologies include hybrid fiber coax (HFC), digital subscriber line (DSL), data over cable service interface specification (DOCSIS), passive optical network (PON) and fiber-to-the-home/premise (FTTH / FTTP), and broadband over powerline (BPL). The wireless technologies include multichannel multipoint distribution service (MMDS), local multipoint destribution service (LMDS), wireless local loop (WLL), WiFi and WiMAX, free-space-optics (FSO), and ultrawideband (UWB). Radio frequency identification (RFID) technique and applications. Fixed / mobile convergence access networks. Enabling technologies and network applications for home networks. Cases studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course,   
   
1. students understand the basic system requirement of broadband access over different physical transmission media.   
2. students understand the basic principles of various kinds of wireline and wireless broadband access technologies.   
3. students are able to compare and evaluate the communication technologies for different broadband access applications.   
4. students are able to appreciate different kind of broadband access technologies in the practical deployment.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course aims to introduce various advanced wireline (copper wire and optical fiber) and wireless communication technologies to realize first-mile broadband access for video and data services. The wireline technologies include hybrid fiber coax (HFC), digital subscriber line (DSL), data over cable service interface specification (DOCSIS), passive optical network (PON) and fiber-to-the-home/premise (FTTH / FTTP), and broadband over powerline (BPL). The wireless technologies include multichannel    
multipoint distribution service (MMDS), local multipoint destribution service (LMDS), wireless local loop (WLL), WiFi and WiMAX, free-space-optics (FSO), and ultrawideband (UWB). Radio frequency identification (RFID) technique and applications. Fixed / mobile convergence access networks. Enabling technologies and network applications for home networks. Cases studies.

Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and informal feedback channels:

- Students are also encouraged to provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, course newsgroup, or simply discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.

| 1 | *Broadband Access Networks: Technologies and Deployments*, Edited by A. Shami, M. Maier, C. Assi, Springer 2009. |

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Mobile Network Programming and Distributed Server Architecture

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 1004

courses.description: This course studies the essentials, advanced topics and emerging technologies on mobile network programming on two popular mobile platforms - Android and IOS. Topics include the mobile programming language fundamentals, application framework, application components, network programming, multithreading and so on. Further, different distributed server architectures and models that can offer scalability and extensibility will be highlighted.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:   
1. gain the technical know-how on network programming on two popular mobile platforms (Android, IOS);   
2. understand about emerging technologies and advanced topics that are happening on mobile platforms; and    
3. understand the basics on network server programming and distributed server architecture.
courses.course_syllabus: In this course, we are going to cover the essentials, advanced topics and emerging technologies on mobile network programming on two popular platforms, such as Android and IOS. Further, we will discuss the distributed server architecture that can support a vast amount of traffic and data. The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.

3. Smartphone Development Beginner Series http://www.codeproject.com/Zones/Mobile/   
   
4. Tom White, “HADOOP The Definitive Guide”, O’Reilly, 2010   
   
5. Lars George, “HBASE The Definitive Guide”, O’Reilly, 2011

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Social Media Analytics
courses.description: This course gives an overview of social media, studies how different tools in information science can be used to analyse social media content, and how these results can be useful in different applications. This course will cover both knowledge in computational analysis of social media and the corresponding social networks, and basic technical skills in Python programming for the analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:    
1. understand the current status of social media and its impact;    
2. perform social media analysis using the mathematical knowledge and programming skills learned in the course; and    
3. apply social media analysis and Web development skills to practical problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course gives an overview of social media, studies how different tools in information science can be used to analyse social media content, and how these results can be useful in different applications. This course will cover both knowledge in computational analysis of social media and the corresponding social networks, and basic technical skills in Python programming for the analysis.   
The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:   
   
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.   
   
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructors directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
This course uses a combination of online materials, journal articles, conference proceedings, and selected chapters from reference books.   
   
Reference books:   
1. D. Easley, J. Kleinberg, “Networks, Crowds, and Markets: Reasoning About a Highly Connected World”, Cambridge University Press, 2010    
2. Russell, M., “Mining the Social Web: Analyzing Data from Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Other Social Media Sites”, O'Reilly Media, 2011    
3. B. Liu, “Web Data Mining: Exploring Hyperlinks, Contents, and Usage Data, Second Edition”, Springer, 2011    
   
Suggested Readings (Partial List):   
1. E. Agichtein, C. Castillo, D. Donato, A. Gionis, G. Mishne. Finding high quality content in social media, with an application to community-based question answering. In WSDM '08: ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Minig. 2008, pp. 183-194.   
2. E. Gilbert, K. Karahalios. Predicting tie strength with social media. In CHI '09: Proceedings of the 27th international conference on Human factors in computing systems. 2009, pp. 211-220.   
3. H. Kwak, C. Lee, H. Park, S. Moon. What is Twitter, a Social Network or a News Media? In WWW'10: Proceedings of the 19th International World Wide Web Conference. 2010.   
4. J. Leskovec, L. Backstrom, J. Kleinberg. Meme-tracking and the dynamics of the news cycle. In KDD '09: Proceedings of the 15th ACM SIGKDD international conference on Knowledge discovery and data mining. 2009, pp. 497-506.   
5. J. Leskovec, D. Huttenlocher, J. Kleinberg. Predicting Positive and Negative Links in Online Social Networks. In WWW '10: Proceedings of the 19th International Conference on World Wide Web. 2010.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Blockchain and Applications
courses.description: The course introduces the basic underlying cryptographic concepts of blockchain as a powerful tool to support distributed ledgers in all digital transactions. The significances of trust, anonymity, and consensus mechanisms are discussed. The course further explores the applications of blockchain and smart contracts in various practical applications, including financial services, distributed systems, and specific domains such as smart city, healthcare, logistics and supply chains, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Exclusion: CSCI5590 or ESTR4326 or IERG4360 or IERG5590
courses.course_syllabus: The course introduces the basic underlying cryptographic concepts of blockchain as a powerful tool to support distributed ledgers in all digital transactions. The significances of trust, anonymity, and consensus mechanisms are discussed.  The course further explores the applications of blockchain and smart contracts in various practical applications, including financial services, distributed systems, and specific domains such as smart city, healthcare, logistics and supply chains, etc.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Imran Bashir. Mastering Blockchain : A deep dive into distributed ledgers, consensus protocols, smart contracts, DApps, cryptocurrencies, Ethereum, and more, 3rd edition, Packt Publishing Limited, 2020.  
2.  Arvind Narayanan, Joseph Bonneau, Edward Felten, Andrew Miller, Steven Goldfeder. Bitcoin and Cryptocurrency Technologies A Comprehensive Introduction, Princeton University Press, 2016.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Data Science in Practice

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

courses.description: Data science is a cross-disciplinary study involving informatics, machine learning, and statistics. This course discusses various components in the pipeline of a data science project, which include Python programming, data pre-processing, feature selection, common machine learning algorithms and data visualization. A problem driven approach is adopted to discuss applications of data science in various real-life examples.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
Exclusion: ESTR4324 or IERG4320
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
1. Apply Python as a programming language for data science projects.  
2. Realize the end-to-end workflow and processing pipeline of a data science project.  
3. Understand the principles and perform feature selection and data analysis.  
4. Apply statistics and visualization tools to present results of data science projects.
courses.course_syllabus: Data science is a cross-disciplinary study involving informatics, machine learning, and statistics. This course discusses various components in the pipeline of a data science project, which include Python programming, data pre-processing, feature selection, common machine learning algorithms and data visualization. A problem driven approach is adopted to discuss applications of data science in various real-life examples.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1.    Steven L. Brunton, J. Nathan Kutz, Data-Driven Science and Engineering: Machine Learning, Dynamical Systems, and Control, Cambridge University Press, 2019.  
2.    Ani Adhikari, John DeNero, David Wagner. Computational and Inferential Thinking: The Foundations of Data Science, 2nd edition,  online textbook: https://inferentialthinking.com/chapters/intro.html  
3.    Jonathan Dinu, Foundations of Data Science: A Practical Introduction to Data Science With Python, Addison-Wesley, 2019

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Internet of Things and Smart Applications
courses.description: The course introduces the principles, architectures, enabling technologies and smart applications of Internet of Things (IoT) systems. Various technology options for smart object identification, sensors, machine-to-machine communications and protocols, cloud computing and big data analytics, security, as well as their design considerations will be discussed. Emerging smart applications of IoT in various fields such as healthcare, transportation, logistics, manufacturing & production, home automation, smart city, will be studied.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty and students in MSc Information Science and Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
1. understand the principles and architectures of Internet of Things  
2. understand the enabling communication technologies and various design considerations.  
3. understand various emerging applications of the Internet of Things  
4. design and apply the concept of the Internet of Things to enable smart engineering applications
courses.course_syllabus: The course introduces the principles, architectures, enabling technologies and smart applications of Internet of Things (IoT) systems. Various technology options for smart object identification, sensors, machine-to-machine communications and protocols, cloud computing and big data analytics, security, as well as their design considerations will be discussed. Emerging smart applications of IoT in various fields such as healthcare, transportation, logistics, manufacturing & production, home automation, smart city, will be studied.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1.    IoT Fundamentals: Networking Technologies, Protocols, and Use Cases for the Internet of Things, by David Hanes, et al., Published by Cisco Press.  
2.    Internet of Things: A Hands-On Approach, by Bahga and Madisetti, Book website: http://www.internet-of-things-book.com.  
3.    3. The Internet of Things: Key Applications and Protocols, by Hersent, Boswarthick and Elloumi, Published by Wiley.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Data-center and Cloud-based Networking Technologies
courses.description: This course explores technologies, techniques, and designs of data-center and cloud-based networking services. Real-world production networks from various cloud providers will be used as examples. Topics include a brief recap of fundamental computer networking concepts (routing, TCP, etc.), data- center networks, multipath topologies and routing, load balancing, network virtualization, Software-Defined Networks (SDN), Network Function Virtualization, new transport protocols, hardware offloading and acceleration (FPGA), in-network computing with programmable switches (P4), congestion control, network management and verification, etc. The course also discusses the main elements of the data-center networking infrastructure, including the topologies and techniques that are used to scale such networks to hundreds of thousands of servers and the services and accelerators that are used to scale the performance of the distributed/ cloud-based applications/ services that are hosted by data-centers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
1. understand how a large-scale data-center networks work in general  
2. investigate the key enabling technologies for data-center networking and cloud-based networking services at different layers of the protocol stack  
3. appreciate the key design tradeoffs when working with cloud-scale systems, and understand the emerging trends in this space  
4. build simple network configuration and management solutions based on OpenFlow, P4, Sonic, and other open- source systems widely used in the industry
courses.course_syllabus: This course explores technologies, techniques, and designs of data-center and cloud-based networking services.  Real-world production networks from various cloud providers will be used as examples. Topics include a brief recap of fundamental computer networking concepts (routing, TCP, etc.), data- center networks, multipath topologies and routing, load balancing, network virtualization, Software-Defined Networks (SDN),  Network Function Virtualization, new transport protocols, hardware offloading and acceleration (FPGA), in-network computing with programmable switches (P4), congestion control, network management and verification, etc. The course also discusses the main elements of the data-center networking infrastructure, including the topologies and techniques that are used to scale such networks to hundreds of thousands of servers and the services and accelerators that are used to scale the performance of the distributed/ cloud-based applications/ services that are hosted by data-centers.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: The Road to SDN: An Intellectual History of Programmable Networks, Nick Feamster, Jennifer Rexford, Ellen Zegura. ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, Volume 44, Issue 2, April 2014.
courses.recommended_readings: Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, by Kurose and Ross

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Big Data Systems and Information Processing
courses.description: This course aims to provide students an understanding in the operating principles and hands-on experience with mainstream Big Data Computing systems. Open-source platforms for Big Data processing and analytics would be discussed. Topics to be covered include:• Programming models and design patterns for mainstream Big Data computational frameworks ;• System Architecture and Resource Management for Data-center-scale Computing ;• System Architecture and Programming Interface of Distributed Big Data stores ; • High-level Big Data Query languages and their processing systems ;Advisory: This course contains substantial hands-on components which require solid background in programming and hands-on operating systems experience.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty; Exclusion: ESTR4316 or IERG4330
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
   
   
1. Understand the mainstream parallel/ distributed programming models for industrial-strength big data processing platforms/ systems.  
   
   
2. Apply common design patterns to build applications for large-scale information processing using open-sourced, industrial-strength big data platforms.  
   
   
3. Understand the system architecture, operating principles and design trade-offs of industrial-strength big data processing platforms/ systems.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:  
   
   
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.   
   
   
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Software Design and Development

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2

courses.description: This course introduces basic programming methodology and provides students experience in designing, implementing, testing large programs using Java. Topics include basic Java programming, object-oriented programming, web application development and software development methodologies.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students of MSc in Information Science and Technology Management only
Exclusion: Not for students who have taken CSCI3100 or ENGG3820 or ESTR3308 or IERG3080.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
1. To deliver correct Java programs.  
2. To design and implement programs using OOP concepts.  
3. To gain hands-on experience on JAVA web frameworks.  
4. To follow discussions about software development.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces basic programming methodology and provides students experience in designing, implementing, testing large programs using Java. Topics include basic Java programming, object-oriented programming, web application development and software development methodologies.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.

2. Robert C. Martin, Clean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship, Pearson, 2008  
3. Mirza Yousuf Ahmed Baig, Build Web Applications with Java: Learn every aspect to build web applications from scratch, CreateSpace, 2016

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Data Communications and Networking
courses.description: This is an introductory course for data communications, computer networking systems and internet protocols. The course topics include data transmission fundamentals, multiplexing and switching, layered network architectures and the TCP/IP model, and common internet protocols, wired and wireless local and wide area networks.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students of MSc in Information Science and Technology Management
Exclusion: CSCI4430/ESTR4120 and IERG3310/ESTR3310
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
1. understand the principles of the basic elements of a data communication systems  
2. understand the principles and architectures of computer networks and internet  
3. understand the principles of common internet protocols and applications  
4. understand the features of different types of data networks in real-life
courses.course_syllabus: This is an introductory course for data communications, computer networking systems and internet protocols. The course topics include data transmission fundamentals, multiplexing and switching, layered network architectures and the TCP/IP model, and common internet protocols, wired and wireless local and wide area networks.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.

courses.recommended_readings:
1. Jerry FitzGerald, et al., Business Data Communications and Networking, Wiley, 2017.  
2. Behrouz A. Forouzan, Data Communications and Networking with TCP/IP Protocol Suite, McGraw Hill, 2021.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Building and Deploying Scalable Machine Learning Services
courses.description: Machine learning refers to making computer perform various tasks by learning from data. It is also now one of the essential components in many online services, for example, to generate personalized recommendations on e-commerce platforms, perform face detection and recognition or predict the arrival time of delivery, etc. Given the widespread usage of machine learning, it is important that complex machine learning models can be deployed in an efficient way to support real time services at scale and to allow seamless update of the models. This course will first introduce fundamental concepts in the architecture of scalable internet-based services, distributed/network programming and infrastructure support for content delivery. It then goes on to introduce how scalable online services can be created and maintained, with a focus on services that involve machine learning. Topics will include asynchronous programming, distributed message queues and brokers, load balancers, micro-services, distributed caches and databases, and challenges and solutions in building and deploying various machine learning models/services in a production environment.Advisory note: Students are expected to have background in computer networking and machine learning.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty;Exclusion: IERG4080 or ESTR4312
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:  
   
1. Understand and analyse different design principles and considerations in building scalable systems   
   
2. Understand the importance and working principles of different major components in such systems   
   
3. Design and develop a scalable machine learning service using open source and commercial tools available online  
   
4. Identify issues and problems in an existing system and suggest solutions to increase scalability and efficiency
courses.course_syllabus:
Machine learning refers to making computer perform various tasks by learning from data. It is also now one of the essential components in many online services, for example, to generate personalized recommendations on e-commerce platforms, perform face detection and recognition or predict the arrival time of delivery, etc. Given the widespread usage of machine learning, it is important that complex machine learning models can be deployed in an efficient way to support real time services at scale and to allow seamless update of the models. This course will first introduce fundamental concepts in the architecture of scalable internet-based services, distributed/network programming and infrastructure support for content delivery. It then goes on to introduce how scalable online services can be created and maintained, with a focus on services that involve machine learning. Topics will include asynchronous programming, distributed message queues and brokers, load balancers, micro-services, distributed caches and databases, and challenges and solutions in building and deploying various machine learning models/services in a production environment.  
   
   
Advisory note: Students are expected to have background in computer networking and machine learning.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:  
   
   
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.   
   
   
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings:
1. Guide to Reliable Distributed Systems: Building High-Assurance Applications and Cloud-Hosted Services (Kenneth Birman, 2012)   
   
2. Big Data: Principles and best practices of scalable realtime data systems (Nathan Marz & James Warren, 2015)   
   
3. Mining of Massive Datasets (Anand Rajaraman, Jeff Ullman & Jure Leskovec, 2011)   
   
4. Scalability Rules: 50 Principles for Scaling Web Sites (Martin L. Abbott & Michael T. Fisher, 2011)
courses.recommended_readings: Different materials including online readings, books chapters and research papers will be recommended to the students according to the final course schedule.

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Advanced Research and Development Project I
courses.description: Student will work independently under the supervision of a faculty member on a research project in Information Engineering. The topic and scope of the study is to be agreed between the student and the supervisor. A project report is required at the end of the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information Engineering
courses.learning_outcomes:
Gain advanced knowledge in the topic investigated and master the advanced concepts involved.   
   
Possess the competency, aptitude, and attitude in conducting rigorous engineering research.
courses.course_syllabus: Student will work independently under the supervision of a faculty member on a research project in Information Engineering. The topic and scope of the study is to be agreed between the student and the supervisor. A project report is required at the end of the course.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and informal feedback channels:   
   
1. Quality of the project report submitted by the student.   
   
2. Reflection of teachers (including evidence from assessment).
courses.required_readings: To be advised by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
1) Literatures in the topic of investigation (to be assigned by the supervisor)   
    
2) Graduated School, The Chinese University of Hong Kong. "Research & Thesis Writing" (accessible from the GS platform)

courses.subject: IEMS
courses.title: Information Engineering Internship
courses.description: This course is designed to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the information engineering profession. During the internship, the student must attach to a company in a study-related position for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor (as primary supervisor) and an industry co-supervisor from the company, both have the expertise to provide advice to the student. To be qualified for award of the subject credit, the student must submit a report summarizing the internship experience at the end of the internship. Additional presentation may be required by the hosting company.The internship should normally take place in the summer term after a student has finished the first two semesters of studies. Part-time students can decide to undertake the internship in the summer term of either the first or second year of studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information Engineering; Not for students who have taken IEMS5920
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the information engineering profession. During the internship, the student must attach to a company in a study-related position for no less than 12 weeks.  The student will have an academic supervisor (as primary supervisor) and an industry co-supervisor from the company, both have the expertise to provide advice to the student.  To be qualified for award of the subject credit, the student must submit a report summarizing the internship experience at the end of the internship. Additional presentation may be required by the hosting company.

The internship should normally take place in the summer term after a student has finished the first two semesters of studies.  Part-time students can decide to undertake the internship in the summer term of either the first or second year of studies.
